subject.geographic: No. 110 Camp Street, New Orleans, La
No. 110 Camp Street, New Orleans, La

mods.abstract: FIFTY DOLLARS REWARD. -- Ran away from the plantation of George M. Pinckard, fifteen miles below this city, on the 9th and 16th March, two boys, GEORGE and BEVERLY. GEORGE, a black, aged about 16 years, 5 feet 5 or 6 inches high, thick lips with a scar on the right side, and the teeth uneven. Said boy was formerly owneed by Richard Murphy, on St. Charles street. He speaks French and English fluently. BEVERLY, a griffe, aged about 23 years, 5 feet 9 or 10 inches high, straight and likely, and very intelligent. He is calculated to deceive almost anyone, as he can read or write. He was formerly owned by T. R. Price on Camp street. He is, no doubt, passing himself as free. There is all probability that they are at this time lurking about the city, as they have been seen several times. The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me, at No. 110 Camp street, or J. W. BOAZMAN, 163 Gravier street, or in some jail that I may get them -- or $25 for either one. ap13 tf
mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections ( http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special )

detail.title: New Orleans daily crescent. ([New Orleans, La.]) 1851-1866

mods.accessCondition: E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments about the collection.

Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Department, Louisiana State University Libraries.
mods.note: Louisiana Runaway Slave Advertisements, 1836-1865, Louisiana Digital Library, Baton Rouge, La.
